SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained generator failure, subsequently took water, developed listing to portside and sank in the Barents Sea, 21 miles NE of Nordkapp, Troms Og Finnmark, Norway on LAT. 71 25' 23"N, LONG. 026 21' 14"E on 28 December 2019 PM in heavy weather.
All 12 crew abandoned the ship to 2 life rafts. JRCC Northern Norway despatched a Norwegian Air Force Sea King helicopter to the scene and airlifted the crew to Honningsvag, Norway for medical checks. There were no injuries reported and an investigation was effected.

On December 27, 2019 about 1420 LT, Position Lat 41-14.5N Long 029-00.7 E, while the vessel anchored at Turkeli anchorage, Turkey, the vessel superintendent who was trying to board the vessel from service boat via Pilot ladder had slipped and fallen overboard into the water at 1425 LT. The crew and the service boat had thrown the lifebuoy to the man in the water and the person in the water had got hold on to one lifebuoy for a while, then later released, no longer swimming and submerged into the water.
The vessel and service boat crews failed to recover him. The coast guard was informed and recovered the person in the water at 1515 LT and taken him to the hospital. The vessel superintendent was declared dead at 1715 LT.

On December 24, 2019, about 1634 LT, Position Lat 01-28.1 N Long 119-15.8 E, during the vessel passage from Bunati, Indonesia to Xiamen, China the 2nd.Engineer (2/E) and the Able Seafarer (AB) who were burnt due to an explosion of paint thinner drums and suffered 2nd. degree and 1st. degree burns. Master provided first aid and vessel diverted to Puerto Prinsesa, Palawan, Philippines. On December 25,2019 at 0102 LT , the AB died from his burn injuries. Injured 2/E disembarked on December 26,2019 at 1430 LT at Puerto Prinsesa, Palawan, Philippines.

Location: Watson Island, Miami, Florida, United States
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire whilst moored at the Island Gardens Marina at Watson Island, Miami, Florida, United State on LAT. 25 47'07"N, LONG. 080 10'47"W at 1930 hours local time (UTC-5) on 18 December 2019. 

All of the crew was evacuated ashore. There was no injuries reported. The blaze was brought under control by local fire service using fire fighting boats 2 hours later but the ship sustained severe damage, capsized on to her starboard side and sank at the berth. Anti pollution barriers was deployed and clean up operation was effected. The wreck was righted and removed with assistance from a floating crane in early January 2020.

A fire developed in the wheelhouse while the skipper was tending to a problem in the machine room. When he came out of the machine room, the wheel house was engulfed in flames. The crew mustered on the deck, prepared a life raft and donned their emergency suits, but were unable to call mayday as the radio was located in the wheelhouse. They decided to stay for as long as possible on board. Another fishing vessel spottet the burning ship and called for help. The crew was evacuated from the ship by helicopter. When the fire eventually was extinguished, the ship was towed to port.

The ship was in collision with the manoeuvring MV 'MAJU 8' whilst berth alongside the Jetty Atlewoleba, Lembata, Indonesia at 1740 hours local time (UTC+8) on 10 December 2019 in good weather.

The ship sustained severe damage to the starboard forward below the waterline and took water. All crew evacuated ashore prior to the ship capsizing on to her starboard side and sinking alonside the jetty. There were no injuries reported. Surveys were conducted prior to wreck removal.

Location: Coast of Santa Cruz Island, California, United States
SummaryOfEvents:
MV Conception,  while moored near Santa Cruz Island, California, United States had a fire broke out in the early hour of the morning on 02 December 2019. At the time, it had been hosting a diving expedition over the Labour Day holiday weekend.

The fire began in a middle deck area where lithium-ion batteries were being charged. At the time of the fire, of the 39 people on board, 33 passengers and a crew member were sleeping below deck and lost their lives. five crew member survived by jumping overboard.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Ha Tinh seaport waters, Vietnam, in anchorage area of Son Duong port, 1.83 NM from Son Duong island,
SummaryOfEvents: On 28/11/2019 at 19.45 UTC, the ship was dragging anchor near Hon Chim island, Vietnam, therefore, Captain decided to heave up anchor and shifting to another location to ensure safety. Unfortunately, the weather conditions deteriorate combined with strong currents leading to ship collide the underwater rocks which surrounding the island. At 20.43 UTC, Vessel ran aground and listed. Ha Tinh seaport provided tugboats to transfer 13 crewmembers safely. Five crews remained on board to maintain the ship. At 01.50 UTC ship becomes more listed due to seawater flooding, so, crew contact Ha Tinh port authorites for rescued and abandoned ship. At 06.15 UTC, NORDANA SOPHIE completely sunk at position 18 07'58" N 106 26'40" E in the waters of Ha Tinh seaport. All crew were safe. No goods on board. Environmental damage not determined.

Location: North Sea 7 miles NW of Den Helder, Netherland
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sank in the North Sea, 7 miles NW of Den Helder, Netherlands at LAT. 52 59'59"N, LONG. 004 36'12"E at 0545 hours local time (UTC+1) ON 28 November 2019 in heavy weather.

The Coast Gaurd received an EPIRB signal, hence initiated SAR operation using Netherlands Navy mine hunter 'MAKKUM', nearby fishing vessels, helicopters, KNRM lifeboats and other vessels. There were empty life raft, life jacket and other debris found at the scene, but no trace of the 2 crew from the vessel. 2 Crew from the KNRM lifeboat sustained injuries during the operation. The bodies of the missing crew from the sunken vessel was later recovered.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sank within Mauritanian territorial waters in the North Atlantic Ocean off Nouadhibou, Mauritania early PM on 27 November 2019 in good weather. 

The ship was proceeding to Nouadhibou to discharge of her catch at the time of the incident. All crew were rescued by local Coast Guard. No injuries were reported.

At 11:34 , the vessel M/V QUEEN HIND, capsized on the edge of fairway channel of Port of Midia, Constanta, Romania.  The vessel was outbound Port of Mida, with pilot on board, loaded with 14600 sheeps.  The vessel maneuver commenced with two tugs as per Master request, secured fore and aft at 1030 hrs.  While pulled by tugs the vessel developed a heeling of abt 3 - 4 degrees to port side.  After the tugs let go of the vessel, the vessel commenced to heel again, even after the vessel's heeling, the Master and Pilot continued to go forward, at a speed of 4 to 4.2 knots. The vessel continued to heel, after reaching about 50 - 60 degrees to starboard the Master called for vessel's abandonment.
All crew has been rescued.

The ship took water, developed listing and sank in the Java Sea, 80 miles SW of Makassar, Sulawesi Selatan, Indonesia at LAT. 05 56'50"S, LONG. 118 34'00"E at 0700 hours local time (UTC+8) ON 23 November 2019. 

Nearby MVs 'SINAR HARAPAN 78', 'MENTARI NUSANTARA' and 'MUTIARA INDAH' the proceeded to assist. All 15 crew were rescued and taken to Makassar, Indonesia. No injuries were reported. A number of deck containers fell into the sea when the ship sank. A local shipping warning was issued.

The ship caught fire in the engine room, and was diabled and stranded on the rocky coastline of Ria de Betanzo, Punta Miranda, Are, Spain at LAT. 43 25'27"N, LONG. 008 15'40" late evening on 22 November 2019 in heavy weather.

The blaze was extinguished by crew. A Salvament Maritimo H-225 helicopter attended the scene. Initial refloating attempts by tugs were unsuccessful. The removal of bunker fuel was effected. A 5 square metre oil slick was observed in the sea, and anti pollution measures were effected. The ship was refloated at 0230 hours  local time on 10 December 2019 with the assistance from the tug 'BOKA PEGASUS' and was towed to Ferrol, Spain for temporary repairs. The ship sustained damage to the hull and propeller, and was subsequently sold for recycling in Turkey.

The ship caught fire on no. 3 deck in crew accommodation whilst moored in the South Atlantic Ocean 12 miles SE of Guaiba Island Terminal, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil at LAT. 23 10'47"S, LONG. 043 59'42 W early morning on 22 November 2019.

The blaze was extinguished by the crew, but the master died during the fire. The ship sustained serious damage and was subsequently sold for recycling. The ship departed the anchorage on 11 January 2020 in tow of tug 'FAIRMOUNT GLACIER' bound Chattogram, Bangladesh.

On 22 November 2019, Alma was experiencing heavy weather conditions, while in the Atlantic Ocean on a voyage from Rouen, France, to Cuba. In the evening of the same day, while the bosun was on deck A of the accommodation, he heard something falling, coming from the vicinity of the accommodation stairway. On looking down the stairway, the bosun found the electrical engineer lying on his back near the bottom of the stairway on the poop deck. The electrical engineer seemed unconscious, The bridge and the master were eventually informed. The vessel was diverted back towards Brest, France. In the early hours of the next day, the condition of the electrical engineer deteriorated and efforts to resuscitate him were unsuccessful. The safety investigation did not exclude the possibility that the crew member either lost his stepping or balance due the rolling and pitching motions of the vessel.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Passenger entered a deep section of the pool and started to struggle, after a few minutes a crew member pulled him out of the water and commenced CPR. passenger was pronounced deceased an hour later by the vessels doctor.

Location: Around 3km off to the west-northwest of the Wakayama-honko Offshore South Breakwater Lighthouse, Jap
InitialEvent: Fatal accident falling on the deck during operation around a lifeboat set up 5 meters high of deck.
SummaryOfEvents: A Third Navigation Officer who was operating around a lifeboat set up 5 meters high of deck died from falling on the deck when the ship was anchored off to Wakayama Port on 16 November, 2019.

SOLASStatus: CHERAMIE BO-TRUC No. 22: Unknown/unspecified, MARIYA MORAN: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The ship was in collision with tug 'MARIYA MORAN' at the mouth of the Sabine River off Texas Point, 3 miles SE of Sabine, Texas, United States at LAT. 29 41'00"N, LONG. 093 50'06"W at 0418 hours local time (UTC+6) ON 14 November 2019. The ship sustained damage to a bunker fuel tank, and approximately 13,600 litres of fuel oil leaked into the river. The Coast Guard and Environmental Safety and Health Personnel attended the scene and oil boom was deployed. No injuries were reported. The ship was subsequently returned to Baine, Texas for inspection and repairs.

The fishing vessel sustained mechanical failure and stranded on a reef at Punta da Focha, Porto do Son, Spain at LAT. 42 42'07"N, LONG. 009 01'46"W at 0420 hours local time (UTC+1) on 12 November 2019 in heavy weather. 

All 9 crew of the fishing vessel jumped overboard. One crew died after being dashed on the rocks, 3 swam to shore and 5 were rescued by nearby fishermen. 6 of the surviving crew were later transferred to a hospital in Portosin, Spain for medical attention. Salvamento Maritimo despatched rescue vessels and a H-225 helicopter to attend the scene. The body of the deceased crew member was later recovered from the scene.

The ship caugh fire whilst undergoing repairs at the Astilleros Placeres SL Shipyard in Puerto de Marin, Spain at LAT. 42 24'18"N, LONG. 008 41'07"W early mroning on 9 November 2019.

The local fire rescue team and tug 'SAR Gavia' attended the scene and extinguished the blaze by 1220 hours local time (UTC+1) later on the same day. Oil booms were laid as a precautionary meausre. There were no injuries reported. The ship was completely burnt out and an investigation was effected.

The ship sustained explosion in cargo tank whilst anchored in the tanker anchorage in Zaliv Nakhoda off Mys Shvedova, Nakhodka, Russian Federation at LAT. 42 47'59"N, LONG. 132 55'17"E at 0800 hours local time (UTC+10) on 2 November 2019. 

The ship sustained sever damage to cargo tank and deck was torn open. 3 crew were thrown overboard as a result of the explosion, two crew member died at the scene. SAR operations were effected. The body of the third crew member was later recovered from the water. No pollution was reported. The ship was berthed later on the same day at commerical port Livadia Terminal, Nakhodka, Russian Federation for inspection.

While loading steel rebars (construction rebar) at Gübretaş Port  at around  05:00, OSCAR-1 vessel was unberthed from the pier due to heavy swell and a need for refastening  in order to berth the vessel. 
During fastening operation one mooring line hitted two crew members and consequently they were injured seriously. Afterwards, Injured crew members were transferred to the Iskenderun National Hospital. One of the crew member was recovered but the other one  died after ten days recovery.
ClassificationSociety1: Veritas Register of Shipping (formerly Venezuelan Register of Shipping) (VRS)

SOLASStatus: Avel vor: Unknown/unspecified, AVEL VOR: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Atlantic Ocean 160 miles SW of Greenvile, Liberia
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship struck an unknown floating object, took water in engine room and sank in the Atlantic Ocean 160 miles SW of Greenvile, Liberia at LAT. 03 13'00"N, LONG. 010 33'00"W at 0010 hours local time (UTC) on 29 October 2019 in good weather.

The vessel struck the floating object at 2245 hours local time on 27 October 2019 about 34 miles SW of the sinking location and drifted NE whilst the crew attempted to control water ingress. However the pumps could not cope with the flooding and all 23 crew abandoned the ship and were later rescued by nearby sister vessel FV 'STERENN'. There were no injuries or pollution reported. FV 'PENDRUC' attended the scene to recover debris which could pose a risk to navigation.

The ship struck the quay whilst berthing at berth No. 51A, Liepaja Bulk Terminal, Liepaja, Latvia in LAT. 56 32'06"N, LONG. 020 59'48"E at 0700 hours local time (UTC+2) on 26 October 2019 in strong wind.

The ship sustained a hole to starbord No. 1 HFO  tank. 100 litres of heavy fuel oil leaked in the water. Local authorities attended the scene and oil booms were laid to contain the spill. Clean up operations were effected. The remaining bunker fuel in the tank was pumped into another tank. Inspection and repairs were effected.

The ship was in collision with an anchored vegetable oil tanker, 'CITY-38', near the JT3 Dolphin in the Karnaphuli River off Padma Jetty, Chattogram, Bangladesh at 0300 hours local time (UTC+6) on 25 October 2019 at high tide. 

There was no injuries reported. The ship sustained a breach in No. 3 tank and 10 tons of fuel oil leaked into the river. The port authority vessels 'BAY CLEANER 1' and '2' and 'KANDARI 10' and '11' effected cleanup measures. Approximately 8 tons of spilled oil was recovered by 26 October 2019.

On the morning of the 23rd October 2019, the FV Dillon Owen, whilst approaching Ardglass Harbour, Northern Ireland, lost power and drifted onto rocks at Phennick Point. The five crew-members were airlifted to safety. Attempts by RNLI lifeboats to tow the vessel were unsuccessful and the fishing vessel remained on the rocks pending a salvage operation. The FV Dillon Owen sank over the following days. The wreck was recovered and sent for demolition.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

Location: Long Tau River, Ho Chi Ming City, Vietnam
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship developed list to port and capsized whilst underway in the Long Tau River near buoy no. 28 off Can Gio District, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam in LAT. 10 32'50"N, LONG. 106 50'55"E at 0150 hours local time (UTC+7) on 19 October 2019.

The ship had previously notified the VTS Centre of the technical problems, subsquent list and loss of a container 2 hours earlier whilst upstream near buoy no. 32. All 17 crew was rescued by local authorities. There was serious oil pollution in surrounding water and oil booms deployed. The ship contained 150 tons of bunker fuel, 97 tons were drained from the bunker tanks by Salvors and a further 33 tons recovered from the river. 278 containers were recovered and 7 missing.

The ship sustatined explosion and caught fire in superstructure whilst berthed at berth no. 9, Damiette, Egypt at LAT. 31 27'07"N, LONG. 31 46'11"E at 1330 hours local time (UTC+2) on 17 October 2019.

Local fire services attended the scene and the blaze was extinguished by 1630 hours later on the same day. One crew member died during the blaze. An inspection was effected. The ship was proceeded to a lay-berth at Damietta for repairs.

While sailing with the cargo of anthracite coal, by 0330 on 15th October 2019, around the Islet of Shengshan, Zhushan City, Zhejiang Province, China, the ship was deviated from her course by the gale to get aground. The ship was abandoned, and 24 among 25 crews were rescued by the same company's vessel but 1 crew drifted for about 38 hours and was finally rescued by a fishing vessel.

Location: Off to Higashi Ogishima Island, Kawasaki City, Kanagawa Prefecture , Japan
SummaryOfEvents: Although a general cargo ship JIA DE was anchoring off to Higashi-Ogishima Island, Kawasaki City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan, it was confirmed that the ship was sinking to the bottom of the sea on October 13, 2019.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Whilst the vessel was approaching breakwater off Segundo, Spain there was a casualty which resulted in the death of the Chief Mate and the Boatswain's injury.

On October 06, 2019, about 1542 LT, Position Lat 30-11.0 N Long 085-43.0 W, South Berth No.1, Panama City, Florida, USA while discharging containers, the twist lock from the container had dropped onto the stevedore who was standing near hatch No.2 Forward had fallen from hatch cover to the main deck between hatch No.1 Aft and No.2 Forward and sustained severe injuries. 
The injured stevedore was taken to Bay Medical Sacred Heart Hospital, Panama City, Florida, USA had passed away at the hospital during surgical operations.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: At 1050 hours on 1 October 2019, the switchboard room and steering gear room of  Su Song in anchor for shelter on the coast of Zhoushan, China were flooded by the seawater came into the corridor through the watertight door of the aft accommodation broken off. One crew who entered the swithboard for repair died and 3 crew were injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
On 17 August 2019, Stolt Groenland, a Cayman Islands registered chemical/ products tanker operated by Stolt Tankers B.V. sailed from Houston, USA for passage to Kobe, Japan via the Panama Canal. The tanker was carrying 20
diferent chemical cargoes in 37 of its 39 cargo tanks. After discharging four cargo tanks of Kobe on 23 September and six cargo tanks at the Odfjell Terminal in Ulsan, Republic of Korea, between 26 and 27 September, Stolt
Groenland moored alongside the Yeompo Quay in Ulsan. Two further cargo tanks were then discharged via a ship to ship transfer with Stolt Voyager. On completion, Stolt Voyager moored ahead of Stolt Groenland.

At about 0600 on 28 September, the Singapore registered chemical/ products tanker Bow Dalian secured alongside Stolt Groenland’s port side. The purging of Bow Dalian’s cargo tanks with nitrogen supplied from shoreside vehicles was then commenced in readiness for a ship-to-ship cargo transfer with Stolt Groenland.

At 1043, vapour started to release from the pressure vacuum valve for Stolt Groenland’s number 9 starboard (9S) cargo tank, which contained styrene monomer. About 2 minutes later, a highlevel alarm indicated that the level in 9S cargo tank had reached 95%, soon followed by a high-high-level alarm indicating that the level had increased to 98%. By now, Stolt Groenland’s on-watch deck ofcer and chief ofcer had made their way to the cargo control room and they saw from the cargo monitoring system that the pressure inside 9S cargo tank was rapidly rising. Suddenly, at 1050, two explosions were seen and heard in rapid succession in way of the tanker’s cargo manifold. The resulting fireball passed very close to a road bridge above the quay.

The ship took water in aft section and sank whilst underway in the North Atlantic Ocean 1100 miles NE of French Guiana at LAT. 15 35'00"N, LONG. 040 10'00"W on 26 September 2019 in heavy weather from hurricane 'LORENZO'. 

SAR operations were effected using a French Navy Falcon 50 Aircraft, a USCG C-130 Aircraft, a US National Hurricane Centre Aircraft and 19 commercial vessels. The French Navy Frigate 'VENTOSE' joined the search on 30 September 2019. 3 crew was rescued from a lifeboat on 28 September 2019, the bodies of 4 crew were found by passing vessels and the remaining 7 crew were missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire in the forecastle, capsized and partially sank whilst berted at Quay 20, Breivika, Tromso, Norway at LAT. 69 40'32"N, LONG. 18 58'57"E at 11 hours local time (UTC+2) on 25 September 2019.

The Blaze originated in hydraulic oil containers in the forecastle. All 29 crew evacuated ashore, 27 were taken to hospital for medical check but no serious injuries. Pollution control vessel 'OV BOEKFJORD' and tug 'LUPUS' assisted with firefighting operations. Some oil leaked into the sea, an oil boom was laid to contain the pollution and clean up operation was effected. The ship sustained severe damage, subsequently refloated and sold for recycling at Hanoytangen, Norway.

The ship sank whilst moored at Stephenville, NL, Canada at 08:30 hrs local time (UTC-2:30) on 23 September 2019.

There was no injuries reported. Anti pollution boom was deployed to contain minor oil sheen around the tug. Investigation was effected.

SOLASStatus: KUM HAE: SOLAS, Zhe Dai Yu 11498: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At about 2030 hours on 22 september 2019, general cargo ship Kum Hae at anchor on the coast of Zhoushan, China for shelter collided with Chinese fishing vessel ZheDaiYu 11498 and was sunk. Among 13 crew, 4 were rescued and 9 missing.

Location: Daiqu Yang, 2.6 miles NW of Huangxing Dao, Zhoushan, cHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took water, developed list to starboard and sank in Daiqu Yang, 2.6 miles NW of Huangxing Dao, Zhoushan, China, at LAT. 30 14'47"N, LONG. 122 37'10"E at 0121 hours local time (UTC+8) on 21 September 2019 in  heavy weather from typhoon 'Tapah'.

Donghai Rescue Bureau dispatched SAR vessels 'DONG HAI JIU 102' and 'DONG HAI JIU 117' to attend the scene. All 15 crew was rescued. There were no injuries or pollution reported. At least 10 cargo containers were lost overboard.
During navigation between islands the vessel hits the seabed and founders. The crew were able to rescue themselves. No pollution as a result of the foundering.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained main engine failure, capsized and sank near the Payra Fairway Buoy in the Bay of Bengal, 24 miles SW of Latachapli, Bangladesh at LAT. 21 27'54"N, LONG. 090 05'49"E at 2000 hours local time (UTC+6) on 12 September 2019 in heavy weather. 

All 14 crew abandoned ship. The Bangladeshi Navy Patrol vessel BNS 'SANGU' proceeded to the secnd and rescued all the crew the following day. There was no injuries reported. The crew were taken to Payra, Bangladesh. A number of the cargo containers from the sinking vessel were lost overboard during the incident and drifted ashore or sank. The local authorities assisted with the recovery of the containers.
During the ship fastening  maneouvre to mooring buoy, ships deck cadet left foot stucked inside the hawse pipe and  his left foot was broken off over the ankle.

Location: Kita Wharf in Maizuru Port, Kyoto Prefecture, Japan
InitialEvent: Fatal accident during closing the hatch.
SummaryOfEvents: When a general cargo ship FIRST AI was under closing the hatch operation in Kita Wharf in Maizuru Port, Kyoto Prefecture, Japan, a boatswain was pinched his head at 10:45, September 9, 2019. The boatswain was taken to the hospital, where he was confirmed dead.
During discharge of gravel from the cargo hold using the vessels excavator, the captain who supervised the discharge from the deck was hit by the excavator and died.

InitialEvent: Provision crane wire parted and the block fell onto the motorman
SummaryOfEvents:
On September 06, 2019, at about 2125 LT, while the vessel Berth Container Terminal No.2, Berth No.70 Jabel Ali, UAE at position Lat 25-06° N Long 055-04° E, the motorman who was receiving ships spares from shore supply truck by provision gantry crane (monorail) from Port side of the vessel. The gantry wire parted and the cargo block fell onto the motorman. The motorman sustained severe injuries and laid unconscious near skylight door. 
Unfortunately, on September 10, 2019, the injured motorman died from the injuries at the hospital where he was treated.

Location: Elbe Estuary, 5 miles SW of Brunsbuettel, Germany
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire in engine room in the Elbe Estuary, 5 miles SW of Brunsbuettel, Germany at LAT. 53 51'30"N, LONG. 009 01'50"E at 13:40 hrs local time (UTC+2) on 6 September 2019.

DGZRS Rescue Boat 'ANNELIESE KRAMER', 4 tugs and other emergency service vessels attended the scene. 3 crew sustained serious injuries and taken to local hospitals where 1 subsequently died. The blaze was extinguies after 3 hours with assistance from local fire services. The ship was towed to Brunsbuetel for inspection. The ship sustained fire damage to engine room and was taken tow by tug 'MUSTANG' to Tallinn, Estonia on 24 September 2019 for repairs.

Location: Huangda Yang, Daxizhai Dao, Zhoushan, China
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took water, developed list and subsequently sank in Huangda Yang 2 miles of Daxizhai Dao, Zhoushan, China in LAT. 30 11'18"N, LONG. 122 29'18"E, late evening on 5 September 2019 in typhoon 'Lingling'.

Donghai Rescue Bureau despatched rescue tugs to attend the scene. All 14 crew abandoned ship and subsequently rescued by MV 'EVER EXPRESS' before being transferred to a SAR tug and brough ashore. The cargo of 48 refigerated containers was lost overboard. Local authorities effected a recovery operation for the lost containers. The wreck was marked with a warning buoy.
Crew member fell whilst cleaning windows overside the ship.

Location: Bight of Bonny, SW of Idabato, Bakassi Peninsula, Cameroon
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship struck sandbar at edge of Bakassi Bank and capsized whilst underway in the Bight of Bonny SW of Idabato, Bakassi Peninsula, Cameroon at LAT. 04 27'25"N, LONG. 008 24'04"E at 1520 hours local time (UTC+1) on 25 August 2019 in heavy weather.

The Cameroon Marine Nationale together with local authories effected SAR operations, rescued 111 persons and recovered at least 18 dead bodies. At least 8 of the survivors sustained injuries and were taken to Limbe, Cameroon for medical attention.

Location: Espadarte Field, Campos Basin, South Atlantic Ocean, 102 miles E of Cabo Frio, Brazil
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained hull cracks and took water whilst moored in the Espadarte Field, Campos Basin in the South Atlantic Ocean, 102 miles E of Cabo Frio, Brazil, at LAT. 22 51'30"S, LONG. 040 21'30"W at 1330 hours local time (UTC-3) on 23 August 2019.

7 hull cracks were found during inspection of external tanks. 107 crew were evacuated as a safety precaution. 1.2 cuibc metres of residual oil leaked into the sea, a clean up operation was effected. Another 6.6 cubic metres of leaked oil was later observed in the sea on 26 August 2019. 7 vessels assisted with further clean up operation. The ship was subsequently towed to the Jurong Aracruz Shipyard at Aracruz, Brazil on 22 November 2019 for temporary repairs. The ship was sold for recycliong at Aliaga, Turkey.

Location: Java Sea, 11 miles SW of Masalembo, Sumnep, Indonesia
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire in the Java Sea, 11 miles SW of Masalembo, Sumnep, Indonesia at LAT. 05 44'10"S, LONG. 114 22'05"E at 2045 hours local time (UTC+7) on 22 August 2019.

A number of passing vessels proceeded to assist at the scene. 306 persons were rescued and taken ashore. 3 passengers were dead and 5 sustained burn injuries. The number of passengers was considerably more than the number shown on the passenger manifest. The blaze eventually burnt out by itself.

Location: Solyanoy Prichal, St Petersburg, Russian Federation
SummaryOfEvents:

Location: Ceram Sea, 18 miles S of Pular Obi, Maluku Utara, Indonesia
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sank in the Ceram Sea, 18 miles S of Pular Obi, Maluku Utara, Indonesia at LAT. 01 59'23 "S, LONG. 128 00'49"E in early AM on 21 August 2019. 

The ship was laden with nickel ore at the time of the incident. Local authorities effected SAR operation with vessels and aircraft. All 25 crew on board were missing. A damaged lifeboat from the vessel was found in Boto, Pulau Obi on 30 August 2019. A lifebuoy and an oil slick confirmed to have come from the ship were also found by search teams in the area. The SAR operation was terminated on 9 September 2019. The ship wreck located in 843 metres depth of water in late September 2019.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At 2:08 on 19 August 2019, in the Barents Sea, the fishing vessel Reval Viking (IMO No. 9211030) registered in Estonia collided with the fishing vessel Lokys (IMO No. 9226736) registered in the Lithuanian Register of Seagoing Ships. At the time of the collision Lokys was hoisting trawls and Reval Viking had already completed trawl hoisting and was proceeding at a speed of about 11 knots. Due to the impact Lokys sustained penetration damage of the underwater part of the hull, significant damage of the hull above the waterline, the starboard side cabins have been severely damaged. Reval Viking sustained significant damages to the stem, upper and lower forecastle decks. Following the accident, both vessels reached the port of Tromso in the Kingdom of Norway. No information on environmental damage or injuries was received.

Location: North Pacific Ocean 805 miles NW of Miday Atoll
SummaryOfEvents:

Location: North Sea, 86 miles NE of Fraserburgh, UK
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took water and subsequently sank in the North Sea 86 miles NE of Fraserburgh, UK at 0915 hours local time (UTC+1) on 18 August 2019.

The ship reported taking in water at 0530 hours local time. 2 helicopters, a rescue boat and 3 nearby vessels attended the scene. The crew attemped to control the flooding using a pump delivered by a MCA helicopter were unsuccessful. All crew were rescued by the MCA helicopter prior to the ship sinking and were taken to Inverness, UK. There was no injuries reported.

The ship caught fire in a hold below the main deck whilst berthed alongside the Seawork Fish Processors quay at Walvis Bay, Namibia at 0700 hours LT (UTC+2) on 18 August 2019 in good weather. 

A crew member was using a grinder in the hold at the time of the incident. The fire subsequently spread to the wheelhouse and accommodation. The blaze was extinguished after 36 hours with assistance from local fire department and a firefighting tug. The ship sustained severe damage. 19 of the 20 crew were evacuated safety without injury. The remaining missing crew member was later found dead in the ship.

All 29 crew jumped into the water, 27 were rescued by nearby Indian Coast Guard patrol vessel 'RANI RASHMONI'. Body of a crew member was recovered and the final crew member was missing. 10 of the rescued crew sustained serious burn injuries and 5 with less serious injuries. All taken ashore to the hospital, 2 subsequently died. Indian Coast Guard vessels and a helicopter effected SAR operations. The blaze was extinguished after 8 hours by coast guard vessels and tugs.

Location: facility of Varadero de Recodo, Inc. SBSR
SummaryOfEvents:
On or about 0127H of 09 August 2019, MV “Nurhuda”, a 216.57 GT wooden-hulled cargo vessel owned and operated by Nurhuda O. Mahadali, caught fire while drydocked at Varadero de Recodo, Zamboanga City.
By way of background, the vessel was drydocked (High and Dry) at Slipway No. 1 of Varadero de Recodo since 24 April 2019, as a mandatory drydocking requirement and for the conduct of carpentry and below waterline repairs. Varadero de Recodo, Inc. is a Shipbuilding & Ship Repair facility classified as a Class C shipyard (CR-000807) registered under MARINA Regional Office IX – Zamboanga.
Based on initial information, smoke initially emitted at the main deck of the vessel at around 0127H of 09 August 2019. Thereafter, fire subsequently started to propagate and engulf the vessel.
At around 0143H, responders from Recodo Fire Sub-Station arrived at the area and immediately commenced fire-fighting. It was then divulged that the fire already consumed half portion of the main deck upon their arrival. Consequently, other fire and rescue authorities arrived on the site thereafter and the fire was then extinguished at about two (2) hours after.

The investigation revealed that the potential cause of the fire was electrical ignition due to short circuit. This was in consideration that the electrical wire connection connected to the adjacent shore-based electrical panel used for lighting purposes was chafed, thus having contact with a combustible material such as wood.
Consequences to the occurrence involves the total loss of MV “Nurhuda” with no reported fatalities or damage to the marine environment.

The crew attempted to extinguish the blaze but was unsuccessful. The fire spread through the yacht. All crew evacuated ashore. There was no injuries reported. The yacht was towed away from the pier to isolated achorage off Ko Thanan where the blaze was extinguished by local fire services later the same day. Anti-pollution booms were deployed as a precaution. The yacht was completely burnt out. Inspection and investigation were effected.

On July 18, at about 1340 LT, while the vessel Berth No.33 Port of Savona, Italy at position Lat 44-18.5 N Long 008-28.6 E, the Bosun who was removing grease and painting on the hatch coaming cargo hold No.5 Starboard side fell into the empty cargo hold tank top about 19 meters height by his forehead and died due to the parted Safety Line.

It was planned that Tank No. 801, a slop and greywater storage tank, would be emptied and rinsed by using a fire hose to spray saltwater into the tank through a manhole from the Main Deck. The Chief Officer (C/O), the Bosun, and an Able Seafarer Deck (ASD) 1 were conducting this task. The C/O directed the ASD1 to enter the tank with him to rinse the tank from the inside, while the Bosun remained on deck. While rinsing a bulkhead from the second platform down inside the tank, the C/O and the ASD1 collapsed. The Bosun observed the two crewmembers, through the open manhole, laying on the second platform motionless. He immediately notified the Officer of the Watch (OOW) of the incident, who then sounded the general alarm. The Bosun then proceeded to the Accommodation to retrieve a self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA). While the Bosun was retrieving the SCBA, the Second Engineer (2/E) and ASD2 entered the tank without wearing SCBAs. They also collapsed on the second platform near the C/O and the ASD1. The remaining crewmembers mustered and carried out the enclosed space rescue   of all four crewmembers without further incident. First aid was provided to the injured crewmembers, however, the C/O and the ASD2 stopped breathing and were subsequently determined to be deceased. The 2/E and the ASD1 were evacuated by helicopter to a shoreside hospital where they recovered.

On 16 July 2019, when the Caroline Maersk was conducting cargo operations at the Terminal de Contenedores de Buenaventura, Colombia, a stevedore
fell into a cargo hold and succumbed to injuries.The investigation revealed that prior to the stevedore’s fall, a container which was being discharged using the gantry crane fell into the cargo hold. 

The stevedore had likely leaned on a safety railing on the cross deck to check the condition of the container when the safety railing gave way.
The investigation found that the corroded condition of the safety railing had been identified by the Company at the time of takeover of the vessel’s safety
management. 

The repairs were planned to be carried out progressively in about four months’ time, when the vessel was due for dry-docking. There were no risk mitigating
measures put in place in the interim, such as temporary railings, cordoned or notices to warn users in the vicinity.

InitialEvent: Fell into Cargo hold, Fatal incident
SummaryOfEvents:
On July 09, at about 0845 LT, while the vessel cargo operation at Nhava Sheva port, India at position    Lat 18-57.0 N Long 072-57.0 E, the Duty Officer informed to Master that Chief Officer could not be located and conducted the search. The body of the Chief Officer who was carrying out his routine inspections of Out of Gauge (OOG) cargo at cargo hold No.9 had been found lying Forward part of cargo hold No.9, row 7 tank top, the gap between the cell guides and cargo hold bulkhead.
After clearing 3 containers with assistance form JNPT Container Terminal, the rescue team found the Chief Officer without Pulse, not breathing and the large quantity of blood around him. The cargo hold under the deck was wet due to the slight rain. The damaged digital camera with zoom protruding out was found next to the deceased Chief Officer. The deceased Chief Officer could have been slipped and fell about 12~14 meters height from the gap between the Cell Guides and Forwarded Bulkhead.

On the morning of 8 July, an Able Seafarer Deck (ASD) dropped his head-mounted safety lamp into Cargo Tank No. 11S. When the Bosun was made aware of this, he told the ASD not to enter the tank and to leave the safety light where it was. A short time later, without permission and unbeknownst to other crewmembers, the ASD entered Cargo Tank No. 11S. The ASD was rendered unconscious, required an enclosed space rescue.  The ASD was pronounced deceased upon rescue from the cargo tank.

SOLASStatus: KLIMA: Unknown/unspecified, LIBRA: Unknown/unspecified, SPRING SNOW: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: In the early hours of 05 July 2019, the Maltese registered bulk carrier Klima anchored at Eastern Special Purposes A, Singapore for bunkers. Bunker barge Libra was made fast alongside. At about 0400, the vessel started to yaw. As the tidal stream intensified, the surge at the extremity of her yaw strained her anchor and anchor chain, and Klima was drawn closer to Anatoli, which was at anchor on her port quarter. The master decided to shift Klima and re-anchor with the bunker barge tied alongside. Subsequently, Klima and Libra allided with Spring Snow during the shifting manoeuvres. The safety investigation identified several contributing factors including, the monitoring of the anchor position, the vessels yaw, and the prevailing tidal stream acting on the vessel.

While the vessel was underway to Durban, South Africa, the crew members decided to carry out maintenance and test the free-fall lifeboat launching arrangement. The lifeboat was lifted by the davits with her aft lashings still attached, and a test of the release hook was then carried out. Afterwards, to allow for maintenance works, the aft lashings were removed and the lifeboat was slid further down on the ramp. As the berthing crew were preparing to dock the MV Stena Nordica at approximately 03.40 hrs on the 17th May 2019, they noticed a man passing by No. 3 berth. He seemed unsteady on his feet and informed the berthing crew he was going to the MFV Ellie Adhamh. The man was then seen to proceed towards No. 4 berth where that vessel was moored. The last line came ashore from the MV Stena Nordica at approximately 03.55 hrs. A member of the berthing party then went to check to see if the man was alright. As he approached the MFV Ellie Adhamh he heard a noise coming from between the vessel and the quay wall. The other members of the berthing crew arrived and located the Casualty face down in the water. The berthing crew then contacted the Duty Port Controller who contacted the emergency services. The MV Stena Nordica launched its rescue boat and they recovered the Casualty. They then landed him at the Lifeboat Station but despite medical intervention the Casualty did not survive.

The Maltese registered bulk carrier Persenk was on passage from Istanbul Anchorage to Ashdod, Israel. On 18 May 2019, she was involved in a collision with Ahmet Can in position 40 46.0 N 027 35.7 E, in the Sea of Marmara. The collision occurred in the afternoon and in good visibility. At the time of the collision, both vessels were in sight of one another, making way in the Turkish Straits Traffic Separation Scheme. They were advancing along the general direction of traffic flow for that traffic lane, albeit on a converging course. Persenk was gradually drawing ahead of Ahmet Can. Although the weather was fine and clear, the watchkeepers on Persenk and Ahmet Can neither did they notice each other, nor discern the developing close quarter situation until Ahmet Can was very close and right ahead.
An ASD fell down an access ladder inside a COT while entering the tank to inspect work done shipyard staff.

The ship struck the quay whilst manoeuvring at berth No. CB-15 at the West Terminal at St. Petersburg, Russian Federation at LAT. 59 52'35"N, LONG. 030 13'23"E on 15 May 2019.

The ship sustained damage to hull. There was no injuries reported. Some oil pollution was reported in water. Anti pollution booms were deployed and clean up operation was effected. The ship was berthed for inspection and repairs.

A freight Ro-Ro vessel was discharging HGV trailers when the 3/O was struck by a reversing trailer and fatally injured. The 3/O was stood on the vessel stern ramp as the trailer was being reversed out of the vessel's lower hold up a ramp. The trailer was being moved by a tug transporter. Neither the driver of the tug nor the 3/O on the ramp were aware of each other's presence.

While underway in the Arabian Gulf, the Third Engineer of POLAR COD fell from an inclined ladder while ascending and landed on the main engine cylinder head intermediate platform (a height of 6-11.3 m). The Third Engineer was pronounced deceased as a result of his injuries.

MT Alyarmouk was drifting in the vicinity of the Panama Pacific Lightering Area, awaiting commencement of cargo operations. As no cargo operations were scheduled on 10 May 2019, it was decided to carry out scheduled routine maintenance of the hose handling crane. The bosun was perched on a bosuns chair, to carry out maintenance on the head of the cranes jib, while three other seafarers were assisting him from other locations. The chief officer was supervising the task. As attempts to complete the job were proving to be unsuccessful, it was decided to suspend the task and complete it at a later stage. While lowering the bosuns chair, the rope, by which it was suspended, parted and the bosun, in spite of wearing a safety harness, fell down a height of about 3.7 metres onto the main deck. Following medical evacuation, it was reported that the bosun had suffered from a fractured left heel and three fractured ribs.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: GUNGNER R: Unknown/unspecified, KARIN HOJ: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: During berthing operation the captain lost control of the vessel which resulted in damages to the vessel propulsion- The officer on dech started to repair the hydraulic hoses on the propulsion gear. During this repair she entered the power pack for the propulsion gear. For some reason she dismantled a hydraulic hose which caused the cardan shaft to lower and squeze her. She was later declared dead.
ShipType1: Other Dry Cargo (livestock, barge, heavy cargo, etc.) Carrier
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
Working personnel were undertaking repair activities onboard the pipe-laying barge “Israfil Huseynov” in an area called the “Firing Line” on Injection Molding Polypropylene (IMPP) equipment (field joint coating equipment) for the Shah Deniz 2 Project in the Caspian Sea (Azerbaijan) on 8th May 2019. At 18:44, during the repair works a flash-fire occurred in “Firing Line” Working Station №7 and resulted in 14 persons being injured. 
Given that the foggy weather condition prevented the medevac, the injured personnel were evacuated by the support vessel. They were initially admitted to hospital in Baku and then transferred by the air ambulance flights to various specialized centers abroad. Unfortunately, one of the critically injured personnel died in a specialized hospital in France. The primary cause of the explosion and flash-fire was identified as the over-heating of the residual polypropylene contained in the IMPP equipment, which generated flammable vapours, as a result of violation of the rules for repair of equipment and safety.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took water, intentionally beached and partially sank in the estuary of the Bucao River near Barangay Bangan, Botolan, Philippines, at LAT. 15 16'00"N, LONG. 120 00'54"E on 8 May 2019 in heavy weather. 

There were no injuries reported. There was some oil pollution reported in surrounding waters. Local coast guard attended the scene for an inspection. Clean up measures were effected.

Location: Indian Ocean, 800 miles E of East London, South Africa
SummaryOfEvents:
Thie ship caught fire in the Indian Ocean 800 miles E of East London, South Africa, at LAT. 34 53'30"S, LONG. 041 48'24"E at 0730 hours local time (UTC+3) on 7 May 2019.

All 16 crew abandoned ship to life-rafts and were rescued by a nearby sister FV 2 hours later. MV 'MAERSK LANCO' was also alerted to assist but stoof down after the crew were rescued. There was no injuries reported. The abandoned buring ship was left drifting and subsequently assumed to have sunk.

A crewmember fell 20m down from the shipboard crane cabin to the cross deck, when the crewmember was about to operate the crane, and was seriously injured. The crewmember was conveyed ashore for medical treatment by the Coast Guard but later succumbed to injuries at the hospital.

The investigation revealed that the crane cabin’s floor plate gave way which caused the crewmember to fall. The floor plate (as a part of the crane cabin floor) was found corroded with severe pitting along the welded joint which had thinned the material. The Company’s Planned Maintenance System (PMS) incorporated a quarterly inspection schedule recommended by the crane manufacturer. The crewmember who conducted the inspections, and operators of the crane, did not notice the corrosions of the floor plate over a period of time. The crane manufacturer deemed such inspections to only be carried out by their authorised and trained personnel. The crane manufacturer had not included the scope of inspection required for the crane cabin, including what was to be inspected and how the inspection was to be carried out. 

The design of the crane cabin required the operator to stand on the floor plate, albeit temporarily, adding weight on the plate which posed a risk to the operator, especially when the floor plate was corroded. The investigation team thus opined that the design of the crane cabin could be improved by providing additional load bearing support for the floor plate and on the design of the seat arrangement.
Crew member fatality due to an a fall from deck 3 to deck 2.

InitialEvent: crushed in between Provision crane and railing.
SummaryOfEvents:
On May 04, 2019 at about 1140 LT, vessel passage from Port Klang, Malaysia to Kaohsiung, Taiwan at position Lat 09-18.2 N Long 109-48.1 E, the Able Seafarer (AB) who was painting at the provision crane at the bulkhead of accommodation had squeezed in between provision crane and railing. He had injuries to his cheat.
The Master contacted to Keelung Hospital Ministry of Health through the company and had suggested to deviate at position Lat 10-25.5N Long 110-25.9E. Vessel deviated to Vungtau, Vietnam and arrived at 2130 LT on May 04, 2019. The injured crew was transferred to the hospital at 2328 LT. On May 05, 2019 at 1235 LT the Chief Officer who left for the hospital with injured crew came back with the death certificate.

Location: Mediterranean Sea, 12 miles E of Cerbere, Spain
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire and subsequently sank in the Mediterranean Sea 12 miles E of Cerbere, Spain in Lat. 42 26'45"N, LONG. 003 24'35"E at 0720 hours local time (UTC+2) on 3 May 2019 in good weather.

3 crew were rescued by nearby FV 'BERTO', the body of the fourth crew member was also recovered. Salvamento rescue boats 'ALNILAM' and 'SIRIUS' and AW-139 helicopter 'HELIMER 201' attended the scene. The ship was burned almost to the waterline before sinking.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: During maintenance on the inert gas scrubber pump starter panel, the Electrician was electrocuted. The Electrician, who had been working alone, was unresponsive when found by crewmembers. His head and hands were inside a local group starter panel cabinet. The Electrician was provided first aid, however, he was pronounced deceased.

SOLASStatus: BRAAKMAN: Unknown/unspecified, KLARA: Unknown/unspecified, POSIDANA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Klara was enroute to Ghent, Belgium, laden with linseed. A Dutch pilot was on board. Posidana was an outbound ship, assisted by two tugs Braakman and Union 5, navigating slightly on the starboard side of the Canal. Klara adjusted her course to pass Posidana on the port side. When Klara was close to the bank on her starboard, the pilot steadied the vessel parallel to the shoreline. As the two ships approached each other, Klara took a sudden and an uncontrollable sheer to port side. An immediate reaction on the helm, bow thruster and main engine speed had no effect. Klara continued swinging to port and collided into Braakman and pushed her against the opposite bank. Klara, now almost perpendicular to the Canal, was hit by Posidana on her starboard side. The collision occurred at night and in moderate to good visibility.

Location: Arabian Sea, 4 miles NW of Vasco da Gama, Goa, India
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took water and sank at anchorage area 'A' in the Arabian Sea, 4 miles NW of Vasco da Gama, Goa, India in LAT. 15 27'15"N, LONG. 073 44'17"E at 2200 hours local time (UTC+5:30) ON 29 April 2019 in heavy weather.

The ship was alongside MV 'MARIA LAURA' conducting STS operations at the time of the incident. All 9 crew were evacuated onto 'MARIA LAURA'. There was no injuries reported. The Indian Coast Guard attended the scene.
A male crew member fell down steps, through a hatch from the wheelhouse in the vessels galley area. The serious fall resulted in the crew member suffering a fatal head injury.

An Ordinary Seaman disappeared while the ship was en route from the port of Esperance, Australia to the ports of Huangpu and Ningbo, P.R. China via Hong Kong for bunkering. When the crew realized that the O/S was missing, the vessel was sailing west of the coast of Philippines northbound to Hong Kong. At the moment it was realized that O/S was missing, the crew searched thoroughly the ship without any success. At the same time the Master gave command for the ship to change course and commence a Search and Rescue operation. After a fruitless search mission for 38 hours the vessel received orders to cease the Search and Rescue operation and resume her original course.The body of O/S 1 was never found.

Location: Gulf of Guinea near Caroco Island, Sao Tome and Principe
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sank in the Gulf of Guinea near Caroco Island, Sao Tome and Principe early morning on 25 April 2019.

 55 persons rescued by local fishing boats, 7 bodies were recovered and 10 went missing. The Portuguese Navy Patrol vessel 'ZAIRE' assisted with ongoing SAR operations.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At 2240 hours on 22 April 2019, there was an explosion in one cargo hold of a general cargo ship Chol Bong San underway at the anchorage of Lianyungang port, China. One crew who entered the cargo hold for welding died and another crew was injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: VIRGO 18: Unknown/unspecified, WINDU KARSA DWITYA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship was in collision with MV 'VIRGO 18' in the Sunda Strait off the breakwater whilst departing Merak, Indonesia at LAT. 05 55'26"S, LONG. 105 59'22"E at 1630 hours local time (UTC+7) on 22 April 2019. 

The ship sustained severe damage to starboard bridge wing and upper deck. There was no pollution reported. 1 crew member fell overboard and was later found dead. 1 passenger sustained injuries and was given medical attention. The local authorities attended the scene. The ship returned to Merak, Indonesia for disembarkation of passengers and inspection. It subsequently arrived at the PT Samudra Marine Indonesia Shipyard at Bojonegara, Indonesia on 9 May 2019 for repairs.

APL Danube was transiting Southbound through the Suez Canal, en route to her destination. The weather was clear and the sea was reported to be smooth. A pilot had embarked earlier and was providing navigational advice to the master. While approaching the Km 133 mark, the vessel suddenly started to swing to starboard. The helm was ordered hard over to port and the main engines revolutions (rpm) of the vessel were increased in an attempt to correct the heading. However, APL Danube continued to swing to starboard until she ran aground by her bow. The main engine was set to full astern, leading to the vessel running aground by her stern shortly after. As a result, the vessel lost her steering capability and was later refloated with the assistance of two tugs. APL Danube was eventually towed to a dry dock in Dubai for repairs. The immediate cause of the accident was identified to be loss of steering due to bank effect.

Location: Celtic Sea, 27 miles SW of Gwennap Head, Cornwall, United Kingdom
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained explosion and caught fire in cargo hold no. 2 and 3 whilst underway in the Celtic Sea, 27 miles SW of Gwennap Head, Cornwall, United Kingdom, at LAT. 49 39'28"N, LONG. 005 54'46"W at 1430 hours local time (UTC+1) on 17 April 2019.

3 crew members sustained burn injuries and airlifted by helicopter to Plymouth, United Kingdom for medical attention, 1 subsequently died. The blaze was extinguished by crew. The ship sustained damage to no. 2 and 3 hatch covers. The ship proceeded to Mount's Bay for Coast Guard inspection and to anchorage off Falmouth, United Kingdom for further investigation, the explosion occurred whilst hot work was being carried out. The ship later arrived at Rotterdam, Netherlands on 22 April 2019 for repairs.

Location: Jawahar Dweep Marine Oil Terminal, Mumbia, India
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained explosion and caught fire in the inert gas room whilst discharging cargo at Berth JD-04, Jawahar Dweep Marine Oil Terminal, Mumbai, India at LAT. 18 56'27"N, LONG. 072 53'56"E at 2130 hours local time (UTC+5:30) on 13 April 2019. 

The blaze was extinguished by crew using portable extinguishers. The extent of the damage to the sihp was unknown. 3 crew sustained severe burn injuries and were taken to hospital, 1 subsequently died 2 days later and a second on 24 April 2019. The ship was then shifted to an outer anchorage off Mumbai for inspection and repairs.

Location: Red Sea, 75 miles SW of Farasan Island, Saudi Arabia
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire whilst underway in the Red Sea, 74 miles SW of Farasan Island, Saudi Arabia at LAT. 16 16'04"N, LONG. 041 04'00"E at 0430 hours local time (UTC+3) on 8 April 2019.

All 31 crew were evacuated with assistance from Saudi Royal Navy and Saudi Border Guard vessels and taken to Jazan, Saudi Arabia. No injuries was reported. The ship completely burnt out.

SummaryOfEvents: At 1945 hours on 6 April 2019, general cargo ship Ryon Hwa 2 underway at 15nm southwards Sanya, Hainan Dao, China collided with China fishing vessel Qiong Lin Yu 60017 and san. Despite the crew of RYon Hwa 2 requested assitance, the fishing vessel ran away after turning the accident site several times. The crews were rescued by another fishing vessel.

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sank in the South China Sea, 9 miles SW of Ximaozhou, Sanya, Hainan, China at LAT. 18 08'00"N, LONG. 109 16'12"E circa 5 April 2019.

Navigation warning was issued by local maritime authorities.

Location: Astilleros Cernaval Shipyard, San Roque, Spain
InitialEvent: Fell into the cargo hold, Fatal incident
SummaryOfEvents: On April 05, 2019 about 0710 LT, while vessel preparing to leave the berth at Astilleros Cernaval Shipyard, San Roque, Spain, position Lat 36-10 N long 006-22W, the 3/O whom just had handed over his duty to 2nd.Officer (2/O) about 14 minutes ago was found without a sign of life with injuries inside cargo hold No.4 by the duty Able Seafarer (AB). The deceased 3/O assumed to has fallen from cross walk located between cargo hold No.3 and cargo hold No.4.

Before dawn on April 5, 2019, AUSTRAL anchored in the west of the island of Amsterdam. As soon as the sun rises, the four boat are going to leave to set up their potters. One of them anchors its 28 pots and leaves to prospect south in order to see if it is possible to anchor the pots after the first lift. When he heads north to join and raise his pots, he is caught by a breaking wave that capsizes him. The three members of the boat decide to swim ashore. Only the two of the three sailor will succeed. Unconscious in the water, the seaman is brought back to the coast by the chiefr but cannot be revived.

On April 5, 2019, the trawler JULIAN BIHAN is fishing for lobster off the coast of Penmarch. Around 2 p.m., after releasing his fishing gear for a 3rd line, the skipper raises the sorting table by the caliorne with the hydraulic controls located on the wheelhouse. He did not notice that the seaman on the port side was leaning over the table when he should have withdrawn. The seaman is trapped between the table that goes up and the port trawl reel. Alerted by the 2nd seaman, the skipper interrupts the maneuver and goes down to the deck to free the seaman who is inanimate. Given the severity of the injuries, the skipper alerted the emergency services. An attempt at resuscitation was initiated by the crew. The medical team was launched on board 1 hour 30 minutes after the accident and could only note the death of the seaman. During a routine operation of lifting the sorting table loaded with langoustines, a seaman was crushed between the table and the trawl reel above, causing his death. The post mortem toxicological analysis demonstrated that the seaman took a narcotic product at a toxic dose. Probably due to fainting, the seaman had his upper body on the sorting table. The skipper, having no visibility on the port side where the seaman was located, maintained the lifting action he commanded from the wheelhouse. This fatal accident reminds that the consumption of psychoactive substances endangers the health and safety of seafarers, especially when fishing. Furthermore, the layout and the absence of monitoring equipment on board did not allow the skipper to have a complete view of the working deck.

The ship sustained collapse of crane jib whilst discharging cargo at Pontianak, Indonesia at LAT. 00 00'26"N, LONG. 109 17'48"E on 4 April 2019 evening. 

2 Dock workers died in the incidentl. Insepection and investigation were effected.

Vessel Medi Zouz was at ISKENDERUN, TURKEY, anchorage. This incident happened while transferring equipment. After completion of cleaning operation in Cargo Hold #4 as agreed with cleaning team leader crew member had assisted to transfer the staging from Hold #4 to Hold #5. Staging was secured to hook on crane #4 and tried to lift. At that time it was observed that construction was not stable and unsafe for transferring. Transfer was suspended by crew and it was agreed that cleaning team will reinforce / tight fittings. Crane #4 remain connected to top of the staging to keep it steady. One of the cleaning team member climbed on the staging for reinforcing and accidentally fell down on deck.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The crew were lashing a stack of logs to the deck of the ship. They were using a ship’s crane to tighten wire ropes on the stack, when a wire rope broke and recoiled, striking a crew member. One crew member died from their injuries and another was injured.

Location: Huangze Yang, 4 miles S of Xilvhuashan Dao, Zhejiang, China

The ship caught fire in the gallery whilst anchored at Lvhuashan South Anchorage in Huangze Yang 4 miles S of Xilvhuashan Dao, Zhejiang, China in LAT. 30 45'24"N, LONG. 122 38'12"E at 0652 hours local time (UTC+8) on 1 April 2019 in good weather.

The local authorities despatched 4 vessels to the scene. 15 crew were rescued by SAR tug 'DONG HAI JIU 118' with assistance from a helicopter. The remaining 2 crew were found dead. The blaze was later on extinguished and the ship was remained at the scene for inspection. The extent of damage was unknown. The ship subsequently arrived at a shipyard at Shanghai, China on 10 May 2019 for repairs.

As the multipurpose boat (the skiff) was still on the slope of the fishing vessel AVEL VOR, one of the crew (the second mate) fell to the water while attempting to let go the hook that was jammed. Despite the immediate actions taken by the crew and the French MRCC, the second mate was not found again. The two contributing factors were: 1. the action of the second mate while the boat was not secured. 2. the fact that the second mate was not wearing his PFD.

Location: North Atlantic Ocean off the East Coast of the United States
