The ship sustained heavy weather damage in the North Atlantic Ocean off the East Coast of the United States circa 28 March 2019.

There were around 12 to 16 containers lost due to overboard, one of the containers struck the hull causing a 15 square inch crack in a fuel tank. Approximately 315 tons of HFO leaked into the water, continuing leak was noticed by crew on arrival at container terminal at Staten Island, NY, United States. Oil boom was laid to prevent pollution spreading. Clean-up operation was effected using skimmers and vacuum trucks and trailers. Inspection and repairs were effected, USCG subsequently cleared the ship for departure.

At about 1225 UTC+1 on 27 March 2019,  the skipper/owner of the single-handed creel boat Sea Mist, became entangled in a back rope while shooting creels and was hauled overboard.

No-one witnessed the accident. However, the skipper’s son, who was nearby on his own fishing vessel, Ocean Lee, saw Sea Mist circling shortly afterwards and raised the alarm. At 1321, Sea Mist’s skipper was recovered from the water by the crew from a Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) lifeboat. He was declared deceased on arrival at hospital.

Whilst MT Aseem was approaching her destination, she noticed another vessel, MT Shinyo Ocean proceed outwards through the designated passage channel. Communication was established over the VHF and a suitable course of action was agreed upon. However, about 20 minutes later, the two vessels collided and sustained severe damages above and below the waterline.

Location: Sitio número 1 de Astilleros Detroit, Puerto Montt
SummaryOfEvents:
El Capitán del Ronia Píoneer , navegando de noche y como único oficial en el puente de gobierno, navegaba el Canal Tenglo desde Calbuco a al Puerto de Oxxean. Se quedó dormido y abordó a la M/N Aegir la cual se encontraba atracada en el Puerto del Astillero Detroit.
Ambas naves sufrieron daños menores que no limitaron su navegabilidad. No hubo personal lesionado ni contaminación.

At 0245 hours on 22 March 2019, a general cargo ship Hae Song 2 underway was pushed by the tidal current and collided with a general cargo ship Hae Song 3 in anchor on the coast of Ningbo, China. Hae Song 2 took actions for grounding but sank.

On March 21, 2019, about 1050 LT, Position Lat 39-04.4 N Long 014-47.8 E, during the vessel passage from Piraeus, Greece to Livorno, Italy, Fire broke out in cargo hold No.7 bay 54 Starboard side. Fire Fighting team with Fireman out fits went into the cargo hold and found the smoke came out from two open top containers from bay 580912 and started boundary cooling. The smoke became heavy in cargo hold No.7, Master evacuated all crews, closed all dampers, hatch openings and sealed the cargo hold. 
On March 21, 2019, 1150 LT, the Master released CO2 at position Lat 39-23.3 N Long 014-27.9 E. At 1300 LT, the temperature came back to 10°C and assumed that the fire had been under control and kept the fire patrol and continue monitored the cargo hold temperature.

On 21 March 2019, Vermont Trader was lying at anchor at the Southeast Lamma anchorage, in Hong Kong. The second engineer, fourth engineer and an able seafarer (AB) set out to open the engine-rooms hatchway. The second engineer positioned himself beside the counterweight. As both the fourth engineer and the able seafarer lifted the engine-room hatchway cover, the second engineer, placed his body weight onto the counterweight to assist in the opening of the engine-room hatchway. During this operation, the second engineers left leg slipped and became trapped between the hatchway coaming and the counterweight, resulting in a fractured shinbone. He was subsequently evacuated by helicopter and transferred to the nearest hospital, for treatment.

On 21/03/2019 about 07:40 LT, during loading operations of un-accompanied drop trailers onboard M/V Isle of Inishmore, while the vessel was berthed port side to, on Berth No.1 at Rosslare Europort - Ireland, an Able Seaman (A/B) of Latvian nationality became trapped and was crushed between a reversing drop trailer towed by a tugmaster truck and one drop trailer which had already been parked, during the maneuvering of the said truck on the port side aft end of Deck 3.

InitialEvent: Fell into Cargo hold and later death
SummaryOfEvents: On March 20, 2018 about 1712 LT, while vessel underway from Gangavaram, India to Santos, Brazil, vessel position Lat 04-27.7 N Long 081-24.0 E, the Able Seafarer (AB) who was cleaning cargo hold about 8 m height while climbing down the vertical ladder in cargo hold, sustained severe head Injury in cargo hold No.1. Vessel diverted to Port De Galle, Sri Lanka to seek medical assistance. However, the injured AB has pronounced death when the medical team arrived onboard. The NE moderate breeze, low swell.

The ship caught fire in superstructure whilst mooring in anchorage off Odong-do, Yeosu, Republic of Korea in LAT. 34 44'41"N, LONG. 127 48'13"E at 0538 hours local time (UTC+9) on 20 March 2019.

The Republic of Korean Coast Guard patrol boats and firefighting tugs attended the scene. The blaze was subsequently extinguished after 4 hours. 4 crew were rescued and 2 crew were found dead. One of the rescued crew sustained injuries and was taken to hospital for medical attention. There was no pollution reported. The ship sustained serious damage to superstructure, towed to the Bukwang Shipyard at Busan, Republic of Korea and dry docked on 20 April 2019. The damaged was beyond economical repair and sold for recycling.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire in the engine room whilst berthed at Berth F5, Trou-Fanfaron Quay, Port Louis, Mauritius at LAT. 20 09'29"S, LONG. 057 30'10"E at 1300 hours local time (UTC+4) on 18 March 2019 in good weather.

The Mauritius Port Authority and fire rescue service attended the scene. THe ship was taken in to to safe waters in the harbour off Trou-Fanfaron for firefighting operations. The blaze was extinguished and the ship was towed to anchorage in Grand Bay off Bains des Dames for inspection. There was no injuries reported. The bridge and accommodation area were burnt out, the ship subsequently sank in Grand Bay circa 29 April 2019

SOLASStatus: CARAVOS HARMONY: SOLAS, PAN ACACIA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 17 March 2019, the bulk carrier Caravos Harmony, under the conduct of a pilot, was proceeding to an anchorage in Vancouver Harbour, British Columbia (BC), when it collided with the anchored bulk carrier Pan Acacia. Both vessels sustained damage. No pollution or injuries were reported.

The ship caught fire whilst berthed at Quay 3, Port Louis, Mauritius at LAT. 20 09'09"S, LONG. 057 20'39"E at 0230 hours local time (UTC+4) on 14 March 2019.

All 13 crew evacuated, there was no injuries reported. 50,000 litres of fuel pumpd to sister FV 'EVERGOLD' to reduce pollution risk. Mauritius Port Authority and the national coast guard attended the scene. The ship was taken in tow to Grand Bay off Bains des Dames for removal of the remaining 30,000 litres of fuel. The blaze was brought under control later the same day, but subsequently reignited the following day. The burnt out ship drifted N of Port Louis and subsequently sank.

MV Leopold LD was en route from the port of Saldanha Bay, South Africa, to Hamburg, Germany, laden with a cargo of iron ore. On 14 March 2019, the only running auxiliary engine of the vessel tripped and the emergency generator automatically cut in. Attempts by the crew to restart the tripped auxiliary engine and to start the other auxiliary engines failed and on the next day, the emergency generator also stopped, resulting in a total loss of power. The vessel was towed to Freetown, Sierra Leone. One auxiliary engine and the emergency generator had sustained extensive damages, due to this occurrence. It was also found that the fuel compensation damping tank was empty and that the drain valves of the diesel oil service tanks were blanked.

MV Boston Trader was moored at Dar Es Salem Terminal, in the port of Oran, Algeria. During the morning of 14 March 2019, the third officer received a call over the portable radio that one able seafarer had an accident while securing containers on the cross deck between Bay 06 and Bay 12. On reaching the location, the third officer found the able seafarer standing with the sock and safety shoe of his right foot taken off and bleeding from the toe. He immediately informed the master and the chief officer, and helped the injured seafarer down to the deck. A few minutes later, a medical team arrived on board and took the injured seafarer to a hospital. The lower end of a long lashing bar had fallen onto the seafarers right foot, cutting through his safety footwear. One toe on the seafarers right foot was severely injured and had to be amputated.

SOLASStatus: BF PHILIPP: Unknown/unspecified, EDUARDO JUNIOR: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship was in collision with MV 'BF PHILIPP' whilst moored at Ravenna, Italy in LAT. 44 29'11"N, LONG. 012 16'20"E at 0700 hours local time (UTC+1) on 13 March 2019.

There was no injuries reported. Sustained damage to bunker fuel tank and unkown quantity of oil leaked into the water. Oil boom was deployed and port authorities effected clean up operation. Inspection was effected. The ship was subsequently moved to shipyard at Ravenna for dry docking and repairs.

Location: Bay of Biscay. Off coast of France South-West of Penmach
SummaryOfEvents:
The Italian-registered vessel had been bound for Casablanca from Hamburg when the fire broke out at 8pm on Sunday.
No injury or loss of life. The ship sank on 12 march 2019, 188 NM off French coast, at a depth of 4,600 meters

Location: South Atlantic Ocean, 305 miles SE of Armacao dos Buzios, Brazil
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took water in engine room, disabled and subsequently sank in the South Atlantic Ocean, 305 miles SE of Armacao dos Buzios, Brazil in LAT. 24 35'00"S, LONG. 037 10'00"W on 9 March 2019.

All 22 crew were rescued by FV 'MAO HONG 8' which arrived at the scene to attempt a tow. 'MAO HONG 8' arrived at Montevideo, Uruguay on 18 March 2019 where crew from both the FVs assisted with an investigation. The partially submerged wreck subsequently drifted SW and was last observed in LAT. 25 38'00"S, LONG. 038 40'00"W.

Giovanni DP was on an ocean passage towards Antwerp, Belgium. The crew were all mustered to carry out an abandon ship drill. While carrying out a test of the lifeboats release hook, the lifeboat was inadvertently released into the water with the chief officer on board. The bridge was advised immediately and a Scharnow Turn was executed by the master to retrieve the lifeboat and the chief officer. Both were recovered successfully, although the chief officer was seriously injured. The immediate cause of the accident was the failure of the lifeboat maintenance chain.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Mississippi River near Laplace, LA, United States
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship was in collision with moored barges, capsized and sank whilst manoeuvring in the Mississippi River near Laplace, LA, United States, in LAT. 30 02'26"N , LONG. 090 28'42"W at 1430 hours local time (UTC-6) ON 7 March 2019 in good weather. 

The ship was pushing barge 'LTD 14161' at the time of the incident but was caught by strong currents and pushed into the barges. All 5 crew evacuated on to 'LTD 14161' and were rescued by nearby tug 'ROD C' and taken ashore. There was no injuries reported. An oil sheen was observed on a 15 mile stretch of the river. Clean up operation was effected. The ship was subsequently refloated and loaded on to a barge fore transporation to a recycling facility.

At about 1930 hours, L/B AJ BOURG departed the Shell Facility in Ogunu, Warri, Delta state, and headed towards to a Crude Oil loading platform in Bonny Terminal. While underway to the Bonny Terminal, there was a sudden change in the magnitude and direction of the wind. Due to this, L/B AJ BOURG got hit by a strong wind while still jacked down and at about 1245hours, the vessel listed to one side and capsized at position (04 08.660 N,  0060 03.43’E).

The impact of the capsizing caused the complete submersion (sinking) of the barge along with all the diving equipment onboard. The master was injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On Sunday February 17, 2019, the PARADISE leave Falkland Islands to cruise South Georgia with eight people on board. On March 5, after five days of crossing, a huge wave lays the sailboat on the port side, the captain and a passenger are ejected and fall into the sea.A liferaft is launched but several attempts to recover them fail.

The Russian cargo Ship Seagrand came into contact with a  bi-level bridge on the coast of Republic of Korea. Although it is unclear if the captain was at the helm of the Seagrand vessel during the time of the crash, the ship was going the opposite direction of its planned course.
There was no  injury however the nearly 6,000-ton cargo ship caused about a 15-foot hole in the lower portion of the Gwangan Bridge.
The captain apparently ignored radio signals from coast guards to change course, because he does not speak English well.

On 28 February 2019, the master of a dredger was crushed between the dredger and the jetty after he fell while attempting to step ashore to assist berthing the vessel alongside a debris discharge berth.The master had climbed over the vessel's bulwark and on to the rubbing band in readiness to step ashore as part of a self-mooring operation. The chief officer was still manoeuvring the dredger towards the berth when the master took a single step towards the quayside. The dredger was too far away from its berth, with the result that the masters foot missed the quay, and his upper body struck the chains and quayside with force before he fell between the quay wall and the vessel. He was crushed by the moving dredger before slipping into the water. The master was wearing a lifejacket and the ships crew were able to recover him from the water in about 10 minutes. The master was declared life extinct on the quayside. The postmortem examination report recorded that the master had sustained extensive injuries consistent with crushing. The MAIB investigation concluded that the system of work employed for self-mooring the vessel was inherently hazardous, and that: Linesmen were not used, but no measures had been taken to avoid having to place a crew member ashore while the vessel was unmoored. The crew routinely employed the practice of stepping ashore/on board when the vessel was not tight alongside. The master misjudged the distance between the vessel and the berth and attempted to step across too early. The company's safety management system audits had not identified the operational practices, and the general safety culture on board, were below the expected level.

Location: Malta Channel, 24 miles SW of Pozzallo, Sicily, Italy
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained heavy weather damage in the Malta Channel, 24 miles SW of Pozzallo, Sicily, Italy at LAT. 36 24'30"N, LONG. 014 38'00"E at 1245 hours local time (UTC+1) on 24 February 2019.

Some vehicles on the cargo decks broke free due to the vessels excessive rolling, causing a crack in the hull on No. 3 Deck close to the waterline with subsequent ingress of water. The ship developed minor list to starboard. There was no pollution reported. The shpi diverted from voyage to Pozzallo on 26 February 2019 for inspection and temporary repairs. 1 crew member died during the incident and local authorities started an investigation. The ship subsequently arrived at Piraeus, Greece for repairs.

The Saudi customs requested samples of the cargo to be taken from all cargo holds before authorizing the discharge. Therefore, the Chief Officer and one seaman were charged to proceed with the sampling starting from the cargo hold no. 1. When they reached the hold no. 4 which was loaded with wheat bran type commodity, the seaman entered first inside the hold to collect the sample and he fell down unconscious, due to inhalation of the gas used as a sterilizer to avoid damage to the cargo during the voyage. The chief officer as an attempt to rescue the seaman went down into the hold but he suddenly collapsed. The third officer, when he knew what happened, rise the alarm and the emergency plan was activated. The Captain came down and entered into the hold to try to help the injured persons and he also fell unconscious too. Then, the crew members wore clothes and breathing equipment and recovered the three injured from the hold. Due to the inhalation of the gas (the hold no.4 was not well ventilated before the arrival of the ship to the port) three crew members died including the Captain.

InitialEvent: Containers collapsed and washed overboard in bad weather.
SummaryOfEvents:
At around 0030 hrs on 26th the second officer observed that the containers in bay 78 had collapsed and he informed the Master who was on the Navigation Bridge. At this moment, due to darkness it could not be ascertained if any containers had gone overboard. The engine room was informed, the chief engineer along with the 2nd engineer made rounds of steering room, engine room, checked shipside in way of the engine room, sounded all tanks, found all in order along with all parameters. As a precaution crew were advised not to go on deck and charterers, managers, agents were informed of the situation.

At the time of the incident she was in the North Atlantic Ocean, in position Lat 38º 24.3’N  Long 070º 18.4’W, heading a true Course of 215º(T), engines on Full Ahead but reduced RPM, on Heavy Oil (ULSFO),  making good a speed of about 11 knots. Bay 78, which collapsed, had a total of 126 empties, all 40’, weighing 462.1 MT. 
Weather conditions at the time of the incident were overcast sky, barometer pressure 1021.5 mb, temperature 8º C i.e. 46º F, visibility of about 5 miles, very rough seas and high swell, Gale winds with force 8 on the Beaufort scale i.e about 40 Knots, from WNW direction, vessel was rolling, pitching, pounding and yawing heavily.

In the morning at around 1000hrs, when the weather had considerably improved, the Master along with Chief Engineer and Chief Officer approached bay 78 to ascertain the situation. No major damage was observed, the crew were advised to refrain from bay 78  to prevent any incident. Crew checked and tightened the lashings from forward till bay 74 and the vessel proceed to Wilmington where she arrived at and ended her sea passage at 1400hrs, dropped anchor at 1648hrs on 27th February’19.

World Marine Offshore, has called and informed about collision at. 07.41 between the company's high speed craft WORLD BORA (MO: 9684304, Call Sign: OWJW2, DIS, Gross Tonnage: 352, Deadweight: 95 t, Year Built: 2014) and coaster in the southern Baltic Sea at Sassnitz. WORLD BORA hit the coaster hard with a speed of 17 knots, but has no hole in the hull. Don't know about damage to the coaster. Several injuries on board (leg fractures, etc.) on WORLD BORA. The company's technicians go to the ship to assist (6h drive). Both Vessel could under own power sail to Sassnitz in Germany for inspection. The Crew and the technicians was brought to the local hospitals for treatment.

A thick fog invades the channel and the bay of Lorient and makes visibility null when approaching the ship in the passage of the Citadel. The ship flooded, he drop anchor in a safer area to tranship its passengers on another ship. The passengers are evacuated and the ship is brought to a dock, assisted by a tug and a pilot.

Location: South Atlantic Ocean, 32 miles NW of Cape St. Martin, Saldanha Bay, South Africa
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship took water in engine room capsized and sank in the South Atlantic Ocean, 32 miles NW of Capt St. Martin, Saldanha Bay, South Africa in LAT. 32 31'20"S, LONG. 017 25'0"E at 0610 hours local time (UTC+2) on 16 February 2019.

All 10 crew abandaoned ship to liferafts and were rescued by nearby FV 'ATLANTIC LEADER' and taken to Laingville, South Africa. There was no injuries reported.

InitialEvent: Medical emergency for a crew member
SummaryOfEvents: On the 14/02/2019 at 1915 local time it was reported to the MRCC of Jeddah in Saudi arabia by the French GRLS NEZMRCC that the Yacht named LETOILE sent a distress signal to rescue a crew member who has an emergency medical issue. 1.1 At 15:00 on February 8, 2019, the JS Nantong departed the Port of Daesan, South Korea, with a crew of 16 members, including the captain, carrying asphalt (4,082 tons) and headed for the Port of Nanjing, China.   
1.2 At 18:45 on February 13, 2019, (local time from here forward, unless otherwise specified), the ship berthed at a pier of the Qingjian Terminal in the Port of Nanjing. From 21:30 that evening until the breakout of the fire, the crew worked on unloading asphalt. 
1.3 At 16:15 on February 14, 2019, the captain heard the fire alarm sounding onboard. He hurriedly climbed to the bridge and witnessed black smoke rising from the funnel. 
1.4 The captain immediately informed the crew of the fire and commanded them to assemble into a fire emergency team. 
1.5 The chief engineer, who had been repairing, with the third engineer, the expansion tank in the thermal oil heating system near the engine zone on the upper deck, also witnessed black smoke billowing out from under the engine room. 
1.6 The chief engineer pushed the remote emergency stop button to stop the engine room ventilator, various fuel oil pumps, and the thermal oil heating system from operating. He also turned off the various valves on the fuel oil tanks.  
1.7 There were four crew members inside the engine room at the time: the ship’s second engineer, Oiler B, first engineer, and Oiler C.  
1.8 Three of these crew members, excluding the second engineer, escaped the engine room safely and immediately after the fire began. 
1.9 Because the captain had received a report that the second engineer was still in the engine room, he did not use the fixed carbon dioxide firefighting system. 
1.10 The firefighting task force could not enter the engine room, despite wearing firefighting gear, due to the heat and the black smoke. They closed the engine room off and continued spraying seawater around it, waiting on the deck by the stern. 
1.11 As the smoke began to dissipate, the task force entered the engine room to check that there were no remaining flames. They discovered the second engineer, unconscious and out of his work clothes, in the front of the bottommost floor on the portside of the engine room at 17:10. 
1.12 The fire claimed the life of the second engineer, in addition to consuming the fluorescent light bulbs, the oily water separator, the lubricant cleaner, and the control panel for the main engine near the fuel oil overflow tank heating line.

In the early hours of 14 February 2019, a supply vessel while enroute to supply stores to a bulk carrier outside port limits, sank in the westbound lane of the Singapore Strait in Singapore territorial waters.  
 
The crew safely abandoned the vessel prior to it sinking with the assistance of an accompanying vessel. The investigation revealed that steering gear compartment of the vessel had suffered a breach while she was enroute. The breach, which had gone unnoticed, resulted in the steering gear compartment filling up with sea water, which subsequently caused water to enter the engine room compartment and disabled the vessel.  
 
The investigation also revealed that there were no requirements for the installation of bilge alarm for the vessel under the regulations she was certified, and there was no process in place for the crew to check on the condition of the steering gear compartment during the voyage. 
 
Though not contributing to the sinking, the operator of the vessel had not ensured that the vessel was manned by suitably qualified personnel.
The fishing vessel was docked at Durban for repair work when it caught on fire, killing six crew members and injuring three more.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: South Atlantic Ocean, 86 miles N of Port Stanley, Falkland Islands
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained explosion in engine room and caught fire in the South Atlantic Ocean, 86 miles N of Port Stanley, Falkland Islands (Malvinas) at 1900 hours local time (UTC-3) on 11 February 2019.

The fire spray throught the ship which was completely burnt out. 64 crew were rescued by nearby FV 'ZI DA YE', subsequently transferred to FV 'LIAN RONG'  and taken to Montevideo, Uruguay. The remaining 5 crew were missing assumed lost. The abandoned burnt out ship drifted to waters 220 miles NE of Port Stanley whilst being monitored by FV 'JIN YUH LONG' and Falkland Island (Malvinas) FPV 'PROTEGAT'. The ship was towed to Cape Town, South Africa and recycled in November 2019.

Location: Bay , 4 miles N of the coast of Zee Taw, Munaung Township, Myanmar

The ship took water and sank in the Bay of Bengal whilst achored 5 miles N of the coast of Zee Taw, Munaung Township, Myanmar at LAT. 18 57'00"N, LONG. 093 27'54"E at 0430 hours local time (UTC+6:30) on 11 February 2019 in heavy weather.

Location: Bight of Bonny, 11 miles off Bonny Island, Nigeria
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship caught fire whilst underway to the fishing grounds in the Bight of Bonny, 11 miles off Bonny Island, Nigeria at 1845 hours local time (UTC+1) ON 6 February 2019.

8 crew members were rescued by sister vessels whilst 2 of the crew went missing. The local authorities and Nigerian Navy attended the scene. SAR operation was effected with the assistance of local fishermen. The blaze was extinguished 2 days later with assistance from tug 'CTOW AN SOFIE'. The ship sustained serious damage and was subsequently taken in tow to the Orc Jetty at Kirikiri, Lagos, Nigeria for inspection and repairs.

On 6 February 2020 around 06:00 local time (UTC + 1) crew members of passenger vessel “Komiza” began unberthing and maneuvering off the berth in the cove Muna (Island of Žirje) towards the Port of Kaprije. When the vessel sailed outside the breakwater (moving astern), she started drifting downwind under the influence of strong wind gusts and then she rotated for about 90° (pointing with the bow towards the inner part of the cove which is shaped like a funnel). In that position, Master was trying to use the engines to overpower the effect of the wind on the movements of the vessel but did not manage to do so. Shortly after, the vessel grounded on the eastern side of the cove Muna. Consequently, material damage on the underwater part of the hull occurred, but without water ingress, pollution and other damage to third parties. There were no fatalities or injured crew members, passengers nor other persons.

Location: Kangava Bay, Rennell Island, Solomon Islands
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship stranded on a reef after dragging anchor in Kangava Bay, Rennell Island, Solomon Islands in LAT. 11 40'46"S, LONG. 160 18'50"E at 0100 hours local time (UTC+11) on 5 February 2019 in heavy weather.

There was no injuries reported. The ship sustained damage to hull and took water in engine room. All crew were evacuated. Salvage attempts were delayed due to adverse weather conditions. At least 75 tons of fuel oil were leaked into surrounding waters. Australian MSA assisted with spill containment measures. Salvors lightered remaining bunker fuel to a barge in earl March 2019. The ship was refloated with tug assistance on 11 May 2019. The ship was damaged beyond economic repair and towed to Bangladesh for recycling.

The vessel grounded around 2330 hours on 4 Feb 2019 due to strong wind. All crew abandoned the vessel on 7 Feb 2019 without any injury. Oil spill was reported and clean-up operation was still in progress until 1 Apr 2019.
A Wiper fell down a ventilation duct in the ship's engine room while changing an impeller for a ventilation fan. He died due to injuries received when he fell.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The ship sustained explosion in pump room and caught fire whilst undergoing repairs at the Gemak Shipyard at Tuzla, Turkey at LAT. 40 50'44"N, LONG. 029 17'10"E at 1300 hours local time (UTC+3) on 28 January 2019.

The blaze was extinguished with assistance from local fire services. 2 shipyard workers were dead, 10 were injuried and taken to local hospitals for medical attention. Inspection was effected. The extent of damage was unknown. Local authorities conducted investigation of the incident. The ship remained at the shipyard for repairs.

On 28 January 2019, the container vessel Ever Summit was berthing under the conduct of a pilot at Vanterm in the Port of Vancouver, British Columbia (BC), with 2 tugs assisting when the vessel struck the berth and a nearby ship-to-shore crane. The vessel, berth, and crane were damaged. There were no injuries or pollution.

At 1749 on 27 January 2019,  the chief engineer on board the tug Millgarth, fell into the River Mersey from the north oil stage at the Tranmere Oil Terminal at Birkenhead, England. He had released Millgarth’s mooring lines and was attempting to re-board the tug. His lifejacket inflated automatically on entering the water and his crewmates were able to recover him alongside the tug within 5 minutes. The crew were unable to lift the chief engineer out of the water because he had quickly become incapacitated in the cold water and lost consciousness. He was recovered at 1811 by the crew of rescue boat Marine Fire Rescue 1; he had suffered cardiac arrest and could not be revived.

Location: Bay of Bengal off the Bhasan Char near Sandwip, Bangladesh
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship was in collision with domestic lighter 'CITY 19', sustained crack in hull and took water in the Bay of Bengal off the Bhasan Char near Sandwip, Bangladesh at 1430 hours local time (UTC+6) on 24 January 2019.

The ship was intentionally stranded to avoid sinking but later capsized. All 13 crew were rescued by local authorities. The wreck was later marked with a buoy by local authorities.

SummaryOfEvents:
The Republic of the Marshall Islands-registered container ship CAPE MORETON, managed by Ahrenkiel Steamship GmbH & Co. KG (the “Company”), was sailing from Hong Kong, bound for Tianjin, People’s Republic of China (PRC) when it collided with MIN XIA YU 04555, a People’s Republic of China-registered fishing vessel, on 23 January 2019.

As a result of the collision, two fishermen from MIN XIA YU 04555 were swept overboard. A search for the missing fishermen was coordinated by authorities in  the PRC. They were not located, and the search was suspended after six days. The fishermen are considered missing at sea.

Location: South China Sea, 6.6 miles SE of Hon La, Quang Trach District, Viet Nam
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship developed list and subsequently sank in the South China Sea, 6.6 miles SE of Hon La, Quang Trach District, Viet Nam at LAT. 17 50'50"N, LONG. 106 35'03"E at 1512 hours local time (UTC+7) on 22 January 2019 in heavy weather.

All 14 crew were rescued by MV 'VU DINH 25' and MV 'PHONG NHA 01' before being transferred to Viet Nam Navy patrol vessel 'HQ967' and taken to Hon La, Viet Nam. There was no injuries or pollution reported.

Location: 12 Nm zone South from Kerch Strait
SummaryOfEvents:
The fire or explosion has been caused by two  Gas Carrier Mv Candy under the URT flag and Mv Maestro without port of Registry , but believed to have been fraudulently flying the URT flag. Mv Candy has loaded LPG Mix 2,468,824 M/T. Mv Candy had been loaded at port Temryuk, Russia on 20 January 2019 and sailed from the port on 20 Jan. 2019 evening and arrived to North entrance of Kerch Straits and drop anchor at area 453 waiting for pilotage.
The vessel had been allowed by VTS to sail in the port on 20 Jan. 2019 at 2300 and at 2315 the vessel was at Kerch Straits, the vessel had cleared from the Kerch Straits at 0145 and proceeded for the STS operation at OPL behind 12 Nm zone. It was observed tha Mv Maestro had decided to postponed the STS operation the daylight .
On 21 Jan.2019 at  1230 hours Mv Candy commenced  transfer operation. The operation was expected to take about 10 hours, by 1630 hours 800M/T had been transfered  from Mv Candy to Mv Maestro and at 1700 hours on 21 Jan. 2019 explosion occurred on the main deck of the two vessels with white vapor exhaust some few meters above the manifolds.

On 20 January 2019, Sichem Ruby was in transit to Castellon, Spain, with a cargo of sulphuric acid that was loaded, in Aviles, Spain. During the previous cargo operations, the pumpman had noticed that one of the stripping line valves of no. 2 port (2P) was leaking slightly and on 20 January, he decided to attend to it. The pumpman removed the valve and replaced it with an overhauled one. However, as he was tightening the first bolt on the flange to his right, sulphuric acid sprayed into his face and body. He immediately proceeded to the decontamination showers and called for help. The pumpman was eventually airlifted to the nearest hospital, where he stayed for several days to receive treatment. The safety investigation concluded that Sulphuric acid had entered no. 2P stripping line pipeline through the cracked Teflon blank and the ball valve that was being kept open while draining the lines.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Grounding due to breakdown of stearing gear

When the Third Officer did not report at the bridge to relieve the Chief Officer for a scheduled navigational watch, a full muster was carried out followed by search on board. Cezanne was turned to head on a reciprocal course towards the last known location when the Third Officer had been seen.

Location: Off Lamma Island of Hong Kong, China
SummaryOfEvents:
The Vietnam-registered Chemical/oil tanker AULAC FORTUNE caught fire and listed about 30 degree at the South Lamma anchorage of Hong Kong, China at
5:00 hrs local time, on Tuesday, 08 January 2019 while she was en route from the Chinese city of Dongguan heading to Thailand via Hong Kong, China to refuel.
The ship had a total of 26 crew members, all Vietnamese, on board. The crew jumped overboard and 23 of them were rescued, one reported dead and two
missing.
It is believed the tanker had offloaded all its cargoes but, at the time of the incident, was taking fuel from a bunker barge. At the time of reporting no oil spills
were visible.
It is reported that crew members on the tanker had been connecting hoses with an oil barge for a refuel when there were three explosions before the tanker went
up in flames and listed about 30 degrees.
Firefighters were using four jets to contain the blaze. Three more fireboats, a helicopter and a police boat were also circling the scene.

MV Guroni was en route from the port of Klaksvik in the Faroe Islands, Denmark, to Rostock, Germany, in ballast. The vessel was scheduled to take bunkers off Skagen, Denmark. On the morning of 08 January 2019, due to heavy weather, the speed of the main engine was reduced. About five hours later, an abnormal sound was heard, and the main engine stopped. After unsuccessful attempts to restart the main engine, it was decided to have the vessel towed to a repair facility in Rotterdam, The Netherlands. At the repair facility, it was found that the lubrication oil filter of the main engine had been improperly mounted. This resulted in inadequate lubrication of the main engine, leading to irreparable damage to the crankshaft.

Location: Black Sea, 77 miles N of Samsun, Turkey
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship broke into two, took water and sank in the Black Sea, 77 miles of Samsun, Turkey at 0810 hours local time (UTC+3) on 7 January 2019 in heavy weather.

The ship sank within 5 minutes of breaking into two, all 13 crew abandoned the ship into the sea but were unable to board the 2 lifeboats due to the severe weather conditions. Turkish Coast Guard helicopters, vessels and tugs effected SAR operation. 7 crew were rescued and taken by rescue boat and helicopter to hospital in Samsun, suffering from hypothermia. Bodies of 4 dead crew were recovered and the remaining 2 were missing. The bodies of the 2 missing crew were later found.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 6 January 2019 at about 2115H, when the Malaysia registered tanker
Aquabelle was transiting westwards along the Sinki Fairway under pilotage, an able
seafarer (deck) fell overboard while in the process of rigging razor wire as a part of the
vessel’s anti-piracy measures. Search-And-Rescue (SAR) launched soon after
continued for almost 10 days but the seafarer could not be found. SAR was called off
on 15 January 2019 when a body was found (later identified to be that of the missing
seafarer) on an Indonesian island (Pulau Pedang) about 70nm west of Singapore.
A stevedores deceased after being caught between a container suspended by a crane and another container on board.

InitialEvent: Man over Board while rigging Pilot Ladder
SummaryOfEvents:
On January 6th, 2018, about 0540 LT, during vessel passage from Turbo, Columbia, to Cristobal, Panama, the Bosun, together with one Able Seafarer (AB) and one Training Ordinary Seaman(TOS) were preparing the Starboard side Pilot Ladder to picked up the Panama Canal Pilot for entering the inner anchorage area. The weather recorded as wind- NW x 4, Sea -3, Swell- 1.5 m with vessel rolling and pitching. Bosun instructed the AB and TOS to bring extra lashing gears to secure pilot ladder. Hence, both of them left Bosun at main deck Starboard Pilot Ladder alone. When both of them came back about 0550 LT, they noted that Bosun and Pilot Ladder were missing. They tried to call Bosun on VHF a few times, but no response received, so they went and looked for Bosun at Forecastle deck and main deck. Since they could not find him, they reported to Master at position Lat 09-24.2, N Long 079-55.1 W. The same time vessel was entering the breakwater. Panama Canal Pilot unable to board the vessel due the pilot ladder did not rig correctly.
Man over board (MOB) alarm sounded and reported to Cristobal Signal Station, Panama Canal Authority and Local agent. Crews mustered and posted the look out. At 0625 LT pilot boarded the vessel and Chief Officer (C/O) sent out Man Over Board (MOB) alert. Search and Rescue (SAR) operation carried out by pilot boat and tugs as instructed by Panama authority. At 0635 LT vessel dropped anchor at inner anchorage and 2nd.Officer (2/O) joined the SAR tug. At 0736 LT Master decided to heaved up the anchor to joined the SAR operation. At 0830 LT the lookout AB saw Bosun alive in the water at Lat 09-25.4 N, Long 079-54.6 W and reported to Tug Smith Manzanillo. Tug did not approach too close to Bosun to avoid hit by rudder or propeller. When 2/O saw Bosu’s head down into the water, he jumped into the water and brought the Bosun. On January 02, 2019 at 1336 LT, while the vessel approaching to pick up the pilot at Tripoli port, Libya from Damietta, Egypt, at position Lat 32-55.5 N Long 013-13.2 E vessel grounded. With assistance with tug, the Master attempted to refloat the vessel was unsuccessful. The Master noted the strong wind and heavy swell from Starboard quarter of the vessel.

At 1515 LT, vessel refloated and the bow started to swing to Starboard and the bow cleared from the Green buoy. The local pilot came on to the tug and instructed to the Master to stop the engine, Full bow thruster and engine on half ahead to turn the vessel into the channel. The vessel gained her momentum and crossed to the other side of the channel’s Red beacon. Pilot instructed the Master to stop the engine and Full astern.
At 1530 LT position Lat 32-55.24N Long 013-13.4'E ,the vessel did not move and vessel grounded. Pilot and Master tried to re-float the vessel with 2 tugs assistance were unsuccessful. There after the vessel started listing heavily to Portside and the engineer informed to the bridge that within 3 minutes the water level raising in engine room and main engine stopped by itself. The water level rose to main engine cylinder heads. The same time the swell kept hitting from Starboard with wind from behind. 
Considering the safety of the crews, Master abandoned the vessel with the assistance of the attending tugs.
